About Me

Hello! My name is Oliver Lei. I am a data scientist with a Ph.D. in Transportation Systems from NYU, and I specialize in leveraging advanced statistical models machine learning and causal inference. Currently, I work at Point72 Asset Management, where I design trend-driven statistical models, streamline data pipelines, and extract actionable insights for investment teams—achieving measurable impacts like reducing costs and improving efficiencies. I am proficient in tools like Python, SQL, and PySpark. I am passionate about transforming data into solutions and driving impactful business decisions.

Research

Public policy evaluation

Causal Inference

Can we infer the impacts of “stay-at-home” policy on transportation systems given observational data? This study filled three research gaps in the literature. First, the average mean estimators could be biased due to weather conditions, and shifted days of the week. Secondly, the “immediate” effects of the “stay-at-home” policy on transportation systems were unclear during different time periods. Third, the existed studies did not throughly discuss the sensitivities of uncontrolled covairates in the long-term policy impact inference. We used propensity score mathching (PSM) method and regression discontinuity design (RDD) to estimate counterfactuals considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneities and biases related to weather conditions. Some highlights of this study are:

  • Quantifying the short-term and long-term impacts of the “stay-at-home” policy.
  • Data-driven approaches using regression discontinuity design and propensity score matching method.
  • The bike-sharing system and yellow taxi system have different sensitivities to the policy.
  • Policy implications are derived from the robust analyses.
    Details can be found here.

Uncertainty Quantification

Stochastic Process

Traditional traffic frequency models such as Negative Binomial, Poisson, and zero-inflated models study crash events at the aggregate level. One of the fundamental dilemmas is that associating aggregated covariates and discrete crash data without care can result in information loss. This study addressed this dilemma by proposing a Gaussian Process Modulated Renewal (GPMRP) Model. We studied 6 interstate sections from 2017 to 2020 using GPMRP. The empirical results show that the proposed model can capture the inhomogeneous crash intensities at the granular level. Moreover, one application of this model is to quantify the uncertainties during the pandemic. The inferred crash intensities were compared with counterfactual crash intensities restored by machine learning models. We observed unimodal, bimodal, and parabolic time-varying crash intensities in the chosen intersections, which showed insights of how crash hazards vary in a changing environment. This study shows that GPMRP model can be a useful tool for safety analytics at a granular level as the intelligent transportation system (ITS) tehcnologies collect emerging data sources at the time of crash. For details, please find the paper here.

Statistical Inference

Survival Analysis

Naturalistic driving data analysis offers insights into risky driving behaviors at the trajectory level, which are critical to traffic safety. However, few studies discuss the modeling challenges of vehicle interactions that are multi-state and recurrent. In addition, escalation and de-escalation transitions are two competing events by nature, requiring extra care in statistical modeling. We propose Markov renewal survival models along with cause-specific and cumulative incidence function approaches for such trajectory analysis. This study aims to quantify transition hazards and predict duration to assess the impact of off-ramps on driving behaviors at 2 highway segments in Germany. We use non-parametric, semi-parametric, and parametric estimations and select the best-fitted models based on the corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc). The results show that off-ramps significantly increase de-escalation durations by 27% during risky states, while vehicle types show statistically significant impacts on escalation transitions as well. Furthermore, we discuss the limitations of the cause-specific approach and recommend the use of the cumulative incidence function for predicting the marginal survival function in the presence of competing events. here.

How do we balance between precision and recall, fariness and profits, transparency but no misuse? This project designed and proposed proactive retention strategies using machine learning models consideirng those tradeoffs mentioned before.
